content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions relating to the element aluminum, <math alttext="A l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Al</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Write the complete ground-state electron configuration of an <math alttext="A l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Al</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions relating to the element aluminum, <math alttext="A l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Al</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Write the complete ground-state electron configuration of an <math alttext="A l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Al</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom.

(b) Based on principles of atomic structure, explain why the radius of the <math alttext="A l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Al</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom is larger than the radius of the <math alttext="A l with a positive 3 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mtext>Al</mtext><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> ion.

A student plans to combine solid aluminum with an aqueous solution of silver ions. The student determines the mass of solid <math alttext="A g N O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AgNO</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> needed to prepare the solution with a specific concentration. 

(c) In the following table, briefly list the steps necessary to prepare <math alttext="200.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of an aqueous solution of <math alttext="A g N O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> using only equipment selected from the choices given. Assume that all appropriate safety measures are already in place. Not all equipment or lines in the table may be needed.

• Solid <math alttext="A g N O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>AgNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>
 • Weighing paper and scoop
 • <math overflow="scroll"> <mo> </mo> <mn>250</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>mL</mtext> </math> beakers

• Distilled water
 • <math overflow="scroll"><mn>200.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></math> volumetric flask
 • Pipet

• Balance
 • <math overflow="scroll"><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></math> graduated cylinder

Step
 Step Description

1.
 Use weighing paper to measure the determined mass of solid <math alttext="A g N O 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>AgNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> on a balance.

2.

After preparing the solution, the student places some of the solution into a beaker and adds a sample of aluminum. The reaction represented by the following equation occurs.

<math alttext="A l, solid, plus 3 A g with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, reacts to produce A l, with a positive 3 charge, aqueous, plus 3 A g, solid" overflow="scroll"> <mtext>Al</mtext> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>s</mi> <mo>)</mo> <mo>+</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"> </mspace> <msup> <mtext>Ag</mtext> <mo>+</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"> </mspace> <mtext>→</mtext> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"> </mspace> <mtext>Al</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> <mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> <mo>)</mo> <mo>+</mo> <mn>3</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"> </mspace> <mtext>Ag</mtext> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>s</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </math>

(d) The following diagram gives an incomplete particulate representation of the reaction. The beaker on the left represents the system before the mixture reacts. Complete the drawing on the right to represent the system after the reaction has occurred. Be sure to include <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>) the correct type and number of particles based on the number shown on the left and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>) the relative spacing to depict the appropriate phases.

The student finds the standard reduction potentials given in the table, which are related to the reaction that occurs.

Half-Reaction
 <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"> <mi>E</mi> <mo>°</mo> </math>

<math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus 1 electron, react to produce A g, solid" overflow="scroll"> <msup> <mi>Ag</mi> <mo>+</mo> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>+</mo> <msup> <mi>e</mi> <mo>-</mo> </msup> <mo>→</mo> <mi>Ag</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>s</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </math>
 <math alttext="0.80 volt" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0.80</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mtext>V</mtext> </math>

<math alttext="A l with a positive 3 charge, aqueous, plus 3 electrons, react to produce A l, solid" overflow="scroll"> <msup> <mi>Al</mi> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> <mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>+</mo> <mn>3</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <msup> <mi>e</mi> <mo>-</mo> </msup> <mo>→</mo> <mi>Al</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>s</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </math>
 <math alttext="negative 1.66 volts" overflow="scroll"> <mo>-</mo> <mn>1.66</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi> </math>

(e) Using the standard reduction potentials, calculate the value of <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi><mo>°</mo></math> for the reaction.

(f) Based on the value of <math alttext="E naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi><mo>°</mo></math>, would the standard free energy change of the reaction under standard conditions, <math alttext="delta G naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mo>°</mo></math>, be positive, negative, or zero? Justify your answer.

(g) Once the reaction appears to stop progressing, would the change in free energy, <math alttext="delta G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi></math>, be positive, negative, or zero? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.C: Identify experimental procedures that are aligned to a scientific question (which may include a sketch of a lab setup).
